results.title: Glass curtain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Doris Chase Concepts”.
A dance film in which a woman tries to cope with the dimming mind of her mother who suffers from Alzheimer’s disease. Dancer Jennie Ventriss. Music by Katherine Hoover.

results.title: The Mehinacu
results.creator_credit: Carlos Pasini and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Disappearing world”.
The men and women of the Mehinacu, in central Brazil, live harmoniously in the five family houses of their small village, but conflict and separation of the sexes is an everyday fact of life - with the men and women performing distinctly different roles and tasks in order to thrive together. This film is a record of the elaborate rituals that take a month to complete, and are central to the Mehinacu way of life - a unique and colourful system of custom and taboo that may not survive the modern world.

results.title: Masai manhood
results.creator_credit: Chris Curling and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disappearing world”.
Shows the process of attaining maturity for men in the Masai tribes. Starting in the late teens the young men serve seven years as ‘Moran’ or warriors. The end of their adolescence is celebrated at a spectacular ceremony- ‘Eunoto’ - which formally prepares the Moran to take their place as mature members of the tribe.

results.title: Some women of Marrakech
results.creator_credit: Melissa L. Davies and Granada International Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disappearing world”.
An all-woman camera team gives a feminist perspective on the realities of Islamic women’s lives in Marrakech. Shows the taboos and their rights and obligations under Islamic Law from a western point of view. Includes many interviews and documents a real Islamic wedding and the traditions that are followed. Commentary by Gill Shepherd.

results.title: Kataragama: a god for all seasons
results.creator_credit: Charlie Nairn and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disappearing world”.
The story of how the parents of an eleven-year old Sri Lankan boy consulted an astrologer to help them find their son. The astrologer instructs them to seek help from the god, Kataragama, who correctly forecast the boy would be returned in twenty one days. Shows scenes of worshippers of Kataragama who thank him for favours received by walking through pits of red hot fire. Some hung themselves from butcher’s hooks impaled in their backs.
results.description:

results.title: Disappearing world
results.brief_description: This series reveals aspects of tribal life and customs, as well as current threats to the cultural and social identity of indigeneous peoples. Each episode is devoted to a different tribe in Papua New Guinea, Brazil, the Solomon Islands and Africa.

results.title: Understanding different points of view
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall and Far West Laboratory for Educational Research and Development
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”
Explains that to provide good discussion and to understand other points of view the participants should: give reasons, ask for reasons and ask for clarification; while the Moderator should: ask for reasons, state areas of agreement and disagreement and ask for temporary agreement.

results.title: Evaluating your discussion
results.creator_credit: Educational Research and Development and Teachers Education Program and Far West Laboratory
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
Designed to help high school students with evaluating and discussing controversial issues. The topics in this film are: George Orwell’s “1984”; Students Appeal Board; and Police reactions - role reversal.

results.title: The Wodaabe
results.creator_credit: Leslie Woodhead and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Disappearing world”.
The Wodaabe are among the world’s last true nomads. They follow their herds in an endless migration across African borders. They have no houses, no huts and no tents. They live and sleep under the skies. Although droughts have ravaged their lands since the 1960’s, anthropologist Mette Bovin sees their life as a balance between hardship and joy. They have an obsession with male beauty and Wodaabe men wear more make-up than Wodaabe women. “We like to see people who are handsome” says one. The Wodaabe insist they will remain nomads despite mounting pressures for them to settle down and lead a “normal” life.

results.title: The Importance of listening
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall, Educational Research and Development and Teacher Education and Far West Laboratory
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
If a discussion is to be useful it is essential to listen. The onus to keep the discussion going is on both the moderator and the participants. The moderator should: Summarise ideas and restore issues. The participants should: Listen to the other person’s ideas, acknowledge others’ ideas, question relevance. The case represented in this film is a discussion between black and white high school students and a white policeman concerning a fatal police shooting of a black man. The film uses this topic to illustrate skills of keeping a discussion on track (as a mediator) and relating participants’ comments and questions to each other.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall, Educational Research and Development and Teacher Education and Far West Laboratory
